document.text: Zanesville, Ohio Special.Willie Saunders, aged 10 Carl Gunion and John Roach, each a year younger, chil dren of Mrs. Naomi Saunders Charles C. Gunion and John Roach, respectively, started to wade across Licking River, almost within a stones throw of their home. Gunion led, and going over an offset, called to his companions for help. All were drowned. The bodies were recovered a short time after the acci dent.

document.text: Winners in The Virginia Farmer, Yesterday and Today are pictured above with Mrs. Frances Gilliam representing the Appomattox County Farm Bureau Womens Committee. Pictured are Ronald Thornhill, 1st place Tom Cobb, 2nd place and Michelle Ford, 3rd place. Over 40 4th and 5th grade 4-H members entered posters in the contest sponsored jointly by the Farm Bureau Womens Committee and Appomattox County 4-H clubs. In addition to the top three winners who received cash awards of 5, 3, and 2, the following 4-ITers entered posters Blue ribbon winners Sally Coleman, Chuck Thompson.. Tammy Childress, Cheryl Mathews. Red award winners Shelia Woodson, Suzette Ranson, Rose Christian, Susan jygin, Joe Crews, Chris Tolley, Courtney Franklin, Keith McCormick, Latonia Richardson, Ronald Kelso, Stephen Hamlett, and Carrie Pennington. document.text: Winginia. As 1 have not seen any news from our little village for so long, I will try to give you a few items. The crops are looking very well, considering we have had such a long drought. Mr. C. I. Johnson returned Sat urday after a months stay at the Hot Springs much improved in health. We wish him a speedy re covery. Mr. Robt. Saunders is ill. Mrs. Claud Camper, of Lynch burg, who has been visiting at this place left for Charlottesville Mon day. A Soapstone Quarry opened last week on the place of Mr. William Ligon, about seven miles from this place, it will give a great many meu employment and is being worked by a Northern firm. There has been a new post-offlce established in Nelson, at the place formerly kuown as Cash Corner, now Broaddus. Mr.xR. H. Saunders is postmaster.

document.text: Winchester.Claude 1. Kell lean, twice a penitentiary convict and later a fugitive, was held for the city grand jury here, charged with passing worthless checks. Lynchburg.A. L. Burger, instruct or In mathematics in the Lynchburg night school, has resigned from the local school to accept similar work in Roanoke beginning next September. Lynchburg.  E. E. Thomas, of Lynchburg, has been appointed office secretary of the local Y. M. C. A., succeeding G. E. Blankenship, who re signed to go to an association training school, Lynchburg.Lynchburg Lodge, No. 17, Odd Fellows, is advertising for sale its home on Twelfth street, and the lodge is arranging to build a tem ple on Church street, between Eleventh and Twelfth streets. Danville.Rorer A. James, of Pitt sylvania county, Democratic nominee for the unexpired term In the Sixty- sixth Congress, was elected without opposition to the House, succeeding Judge Edward W. Saunders, resigned. A light vote was polled. Bristol.Miss Pearl Lee, aged 23, the daughter of a coal operator in the St. Charles District, was shot and killed at her home at Ramsey, accord ing to Information received in Bristol. The advices do not give the details of the shooting. Bristol.Announcement Is made here that the vast properties of the Patrick Hagan estate, including valu able coal lands and town lots in Nor ton, Dungannon, and Richmond, will be sold at public auction at Gate City, Va., on August 17, according to an agreement between the beneficiaries of the estate and the trustee. Williamsburg.About fifty boys and girls from the counties of James City, Charles City and New Kent are at the college of William and Mary taking a three-day ourse in canning, cooking, Tnatiual training, gardening, poultry raising, baknfcry, and other courses leading to the betterment of their home and communities. Winchester.  Colonel Robert F. Leedy, of Page county, who is oppos ing Representative T. W. Harrison, of Winchester, for the Democratlci nomination for Congress from the Seventh Virginia district, has been endorsed by an organization known as the Jefferson Club, this city, which claims to have a membership of 557 voters. Winchester.A railroad track has been built from Millville, W. Va., to the plant of the Northern Virginia Power Company, near the Shenandoah River, for the purpose of hauling and dumping coal. Conveyors will also transfer the coal to the boiler rooms of the plant. Heretofore It has been necessary to haul the coal In carts and trucks from Millville. Lynchburg.Judge A. E. Chamber- lain, of Minnesota, who assisted here recently in the greater central Vir ginia campaign, has accepted the po sition as head of the new bureau of production of the chamber of com merce here. The chamber of com merce will appropriate funds in the next few years in an effort to develop the agricultural interests of the coun ties around the city. Danville.The gravest concern was felt for Thomas F. Connally, believed to be suffering from mental aberra tion, who disappeared from his home here on Friday afternoon at 3 oclock, and who has not since been heard from. A reward was offered for in formation leading to his recovery, and the Boy Scouts are being organized to carry out a search for him. The family believes that he may have wan dered into the woods and died or, still worse, to have leaped into the river. Lynchburg.  Lynchburg If just three miles nearer Washington than formerly, or, if you please, Washing ton is just that much nearer Lynch burg. and the conditions results from the re-arrangement of the main line of the Southern railway during the past fifteen years. Surveys on now between Washington and Atlanta have been completed to Lynchburg from the North, and this has resulted In 174th mile post at Lynchburg being moved below Durmid. Winchester.H. F. Byrd has re ceived a letter from Thomas W. Mat hews, of London, who is largely in terested in the apple market here and abroad, in which he states that the yield of apples on the Continent of Europe seems likely to be small, ow ing to frost damage. Mr. Mathews expects to be here this summer. Lynchburg.J. H. Brooks, a Chesa peake and Ohio yard brakeman, is at the Home and Retreat here, suffering with a fractured collar bone and bruises about his body as a result of a fall from a freight car.

A good number was out to hear lim. It is with sad regret we note the death of Rev. Saunders Jones, the kneeling evangelist. He will be greatly missed. We were certainly sorry to hear of the death of Mrs. Anna Godsey Scott, of Campbell Co., which occurred in Memorial Hospital last week. The bur ial took place at Union Hill cemetery last Thursday p. m. Mrs. Scott was well known in this community, where she was reaped, and it can well be said  a good woman has gone to her reward. Her husband pre- ceded her to. the grave several  years ago. She leaves several children, which we wish to ex tend our sympathy to. Mrs. Henry White, whose illness was mentioned in this paper some time ago, is better, though She is in a weak con dition.  Mr. and Mrs. W. W. Over- ton and daughter, Myrtie, of Richmond, and Mrs. George Cocke, of Phenix, spent a part of the Xmas holidays with their parents Mr. and Mrs. N. D. Marshall. document.text: While a number of women are lob bying for the equal suffrage bill, it is said that at the public hearing Fri day afternoon a petition, signed by many prominent women,, was present ed, urging the committee not to rec ommend the measure for passage. Bills prohibiting the manufacture or sale of other than safety matches, to tax automobiles for county road purposes, to create a department of mines, to amend tax laws, reducing assessments on the first 1,000 of household goods from 35 cents to 10 cents to amend the code, and to prescribe order of procedure In court cases, were introduced. The Senate resolution, offered - by Senator Echols, of Augusta, for the formal election of United States sena tors at noon on Tuesday, January 23, and a joint election on Wednesday, the 24th, was concurred in by the House. The Senate concurred In a House resolution to arrange a joint session for February 22, when the State of Texas will present a portrait of Gen. Sam Houston to Virginia. Democratic Floor Leader Martin Williams, of Giles county, is strenu ously opposing the proposed tax com mission bill in Its present form, averr ing that it is not fair to Giles and other southwestern counties of the State rich in mineral deposits and other natural resources. Another measure which will meet with oppo sition is the Stenbenson bill to abol-, lsh gambling. Delegate Banks, from Norfolk, says the bill will mean the death of horseracing and bookmaking at the Jamestown racstrack. The Senate and House held a joint session and unanimously elected W. D. Saunders State dairy and food com missioner, and J. Richard Wingfield member of .the State Corporation Com mission. The House concurred in the Senate resolution to do away with the pres ent system of leasing convict labor, and calling upon the joint committees on roads to consider the Governors message relative to roads and work ing convicts thereon. Bills were introduced in the House to prohibit treating in saloons to place local milk inspectors under juris diction of the State Dairy and Pure rood Commission to compel State employes to work from 9 to 5 oclock each day. The Senate concurred iu the House rneasuYe to close the hunting season at once to protect game. One bill of State-wide interest in the Senate makes it necessary to se cure a State license to carry deadly or dangerous weapons. -Senator Paul, of the Republican mi nority, is working in the interest of a measure to have at least one Repub lican on every electoral board throughout the State. The bill for a change in the city charter of Richmond for the creation of an administrative board, previously passed by the House, was passed in the Senate under a suspension of the rules, and now goes to Governor Mann for his signature. Delegate Cox, of Richmond, intro duced a resolution providing that Gov ernor Woodrow Wilson, of New Jer sey, be invited to address  joint ses sion of the legislature and of the Rich mond City Council on Thursday night, February 1, at 8 oclock. The resolu tion was unanimously passed, and when sent to the Senate was concur red in. One of the most Important bills in troduced in the House was presented by Delegate Harwood, of Richmond, providing for the amendment to the section of the code governing the state tax on corporations for the sup port of free schools, pensions and liquidation of the public debt. The present law provides a maximum fee of 600, imposed upon a company with a capital of 1,000,000, while on a company capitalized at 999,000 the tax is 199.80. It was announced in both Houses that the joint committee on roads would have a public hearing on the questions of roads and workirfe con victs thereon, according to the recom mendations of Governor Mantl, on Monday, January ?9. One of the provisions of the charter amendment bill for the city of Rich mond, which has passed both Houses of the legislature and is now in thte hands of Governor Mann for his signature, reads that the city has the right to erect and maintain, in con nection with the city prison, if the I Council so determines, a suitable  workhouse and a bouse of correction, to compel and require all able-bodied i adult prisoners confined to perform anual labor in such workhouse and to  employ all youthful prisoners in the house of correction. Many representatives of the south west section of the state were here t,o oppose any changes in the redistrict ing of the Ninth district, the Dem ocrats believing that if the district is left undisturbed they have an excel lent chance to elect a successor to Congressman Bascom Slemp, the in cumbent, in the coming November election. , .

document.text: Wert. Threshing wheat is now the order of the day. The whistles of steam threshers are .now heard in every di rection, showing that the work is progressing rapidly. The yield is said to be very good. The weather is extremely hot and dry, the thermometer registering 97 degrees in the shade. We aie glad to state that Mr, C. J. Morris is slowly improving from a severe spell of illness. He has so far recovered as to be able to sit up for a short while at a time. Mr. Leslie Wooldridge lost a fine horse last week. Mr. J. W. Forbes also lest one last week, and Mr. F. T. Saunders lost one a week ago. There is to be an entertainment for the benefit of the Presbyterian church at New Store on Saturday, July 14, at 1 oclock p. m . Refresh- j meats will be 011 sale. Thanks to your New-Store corre spondent for inquiring after us. We are still in existence, but news is scarce in onr quiet little town, as is evidenced bv this letter.

document.text: Wert. Stripping tobacco has been the order of the day with onr farmers for several weeks past and a large part of the orop has been sold. It seems that most of the farmers ire satisfied with the prion reoeived.  There is great exeiiement among ths colored population of this section over the report that a bear is on. Campbell Saunders colored, ciaiuii to have seen the bear plainly arid was within about ten feet of hint, when he decided that was near enough to get to bruin, and with bnt little consideration be left bruin without disturbing him and we sup pose he traveled at the rate of a mile a minute until he reached home. When he arrived at home be fell at the door exhausted and could not speak for some time. Campbell not being content with this got a lot of his neighbors! together and started bruiu - to givshii chase, ut alas, brain could not be found and the imaginary bear hue not since been heard of. The col ored people believe it to be t. ue and are afraid to travel at night. Miss Mary Agee is spending eev eral days with relatives at Prospect Mr. B, W. Morris and ohildreu of Bedford and Miss Ida Harvey of lose Bower were calling on fnen s Buckingham last week. Mr. Alvin Woolridge, of Lynch burg made 1 stuitt visit to this coun ty last week. He was accompanied by his sister, Miss Effie. Mr. J. G. Scruggs, is having a new dwelling erected on his farm, near Forbes. News has been received here of the marriage of Mr. Hnnter Wool, ridge and Miss Hester Nash. Hunter is a Buckingham boy, but now re sides in Lynchburg. His bride is also of that city. We will congratu late tbem and may their life be long and happy. We suppose the Forbes correspon dent has gone into winter cnarters, as we have not heard from them for some time or perhaps there is no news to relate from that quiet little town. Who can tell what it the rea son? The Ministers and Laymens meet ing which met at Enon Baptist Cbnrch on last Satnrday was not very largely attended. There was preaching Saturdayvgfemiug by Rev. Mr. Mitchel, Associate Editor of The Religions Herald. As there was not any of the speakers present who was appointed to speak on various subjects, Rev. W. C. Foster enter tained the congregation in the after noon with a talk on his recent trip to Florida, which was greatly enjoy ed bv all present. Mr. Foster has received a call from a church of Florida and we are afraid he will conclude to accept that call. December 1, 1902.

Tbe graded school here under tbe management of Professor James N, Ayers Principal and Miss Bessie Gfown, Assistant, is progressing nicely with a large roll of scholars. Mr. Ayera is a very ooippetent teacher and seems to be well fitted for the work of education. He has bad moch experience tn this work hav ing taught Hie graded school at Well Water for a number of years, where be did omoh for tbe oauie of education. Miss Crowu taught nrivate school at this place two years ago in which she gave good satisfac tion and won tbe hearts of both par ents and scholars, this together with ler thorough educational qualifica tions makes her a very suitable teacher for tbe primary department. document.text: Washington.With 1,500 additional regular troops ordered to the Mexican border and reports of the rapid spread of anti-American feeling continuing to pour in from consuls all over North ern Mexico, administration officials made no attempt to disguise their un easiness. It was officially admitted that there Is growing alarm over what the agita tion may produce and tie possibility of an attack on General Pershings ex pedition. No case of attack on the persons of American residents in Mexico has been reported, although there have been one or two attacks on vacant consulates and other American prop erty. Distributed By Raids. Part of the increasing apprehension here is due to the renewed raids in the Laredo region. Several reports dealing with the situation there have been received. Officials declined to re- val details, but they gave the impres sion of having reason to believe a seri ous purpose waR behind the bandit raid on the Coleman ranch. Three raiders were killed and three captured, one re port said, adding that they attempted to burn a railroad bridge near Laredo, but failed. The new force sent to join General Funptons border patrol, Secretary Baker said, was to fill in gaps in the guard, such as that near Laredo. It will be composed of 10 companies of coast artillery and a battalion of engi neers. The artillerymen will be with drawn from fortifications between Portland, Maine, and Sandy Hook, and the engineers go from barracks in this city.1 The Secretary said there was no present intention of calling out addi tional National Guard regiments for border duty. Cavalrymen Fired On. General Mann, commanding at La redo, reported that a patrol of three cavalrymen was fired on during the night of June 10 near the town of Hachita and Private W. L. Saunders, of Troop K, Twelfth Cavalry, slightly wounded. Two mounted Mexicans, who did the firing, escaped. A message from Captain Burrage, commanding the battleship Nebraska at Vera Cruz, said there was consider able unrest in that region, due ap parently, to the currency situation. There were no evidences of unfriendli ness toward Americans, the message said. It added that the Carranza Gov ernment had been sending troops and ammunition inland. Captain Burrage did not know the object of these troops movements.

document.text: Was not the man who could bring his hand down upon so frail and ex quisite a creature aa Renther was in those days capable of any act of vio lence? Yes but in this case he had been guiltless. She could not but con cede this even .while, yielding to ex treme revulsion as she laid hls pic ture aside, t The next slip she took up contained a eulogy of the victim. The sudden death ot Algernon Eth eridge has been in more than one sense a great shock to the oommunHy. Thdbgh a man of passive, rather than active qualities, his scholarly figure, long, lean and bowed, has been seen too often In our streets not to be missed, when thus suddenly with draw!. Why he should have become the target ot Fate is one. of the mysteries of llfa rils watch, which, aside from his books, was his most valuable pos session, was the gift of Judge Ostran der. That It should be associated In any way with the tragic circumstances ot his death is a source of the deepest regret to the unhappy donor. This excerpt she hardly looked at .but the following ehe studied care fully Judge Ostrander inm from the first expressed a strong desire that Borne associate judge should be called upon to preside over the trial of John Sco ville for the murder of Algernon Eth eridge. But Judge SaunderS sudden illness and Judge Doles departure tor Europe have put van end .to these hopes. Judge Ostrander will take his seat on the bench as usual next Mon day. Fortunately for the accused, his well-known judicial mind will prevent any unfair treatment of the defense. The pro8ecntion,.in the able hands of District Attorney Foss, made all its points this morning. Unless the de fense has some very strong plea in the background the verdict seems fore doomed. A dogged look has replaced the callous and indifferent sneer on the prisoners face, and sympathy, if sympathy there is, is. centered entire ly upon the wife, the able, agreeable and bitterly humiliated landlady of Claymore tavern. She it is who has attracted the most attention during this trial, little as she seems to court it.We omit further particulars which followed to save repetition but they were carefully conned by Deborah Scoville. Also the following The defense is In line with the statement already given out. The prisoner acknowledges taking the watch, but from motives quite opposed to those of thievery. Unfortunately he can produce no witnesses to sub stantiate his declaration that he had heard voices in the direction of the bridge while he was wandering the woods in search of his lost child. No evidence of any other presence there is promised or likely to be produced. It was thought that when his wife was called to Jthe stand she might have something to say helpful to his case. She had been the one to ultimately find and lead home the child, and, silent as she had been up to this time, it has been thought possible that she might swear to having heard these oices also. But her testimony was very disap pointing. She had seen nobody but the child, whom she had found playing with stones In the old ruin. Though by a close calculation of time she could not have been far from Dark Hollow at the instant of the crime, yet neither on direct or cross examina tion could anything more be elicited from her than what has been men tioned above. Nevertheless, We feel obliged to state that, irreproachable as her conduct was on the stand, the impression she made was, on the whole, whether intentionally or unin tentionally. unfavorable to her hus band. Some anxiety was felt during the morning session that an adjournment would have to be called, owing to some slight signs of indisposition on the part of the presiding judge. But he rallied very speedily, and the pro ceedings continued without Interrup tion. Ah! The exclamation escaped the lips of Deborah Scoville as she laid this clipping aside. 1 remember hls ap pearance well. He had the ghost of one of those attacks, the full force of which I was witness to this morn ing. I am sure of this now, though nobody thought of it then. I happened to glance his way as I left the stand, and he was certainly for one minute without consciousness of himself or his surroundings. But it passed so quickly it drew little attention not so the attack of today. What a mis fortune rests upon.this man. Will they let him continue on the bench when hie fijll condition is known? These were ber thoughts as she re called that day and compared it with the present. There were other slips, which she read. The fate of the prisoner was in the hands of the Jury. The possi bility suggested by the defense made no appeal to men who hail the unfor tunate prisoner under their eye at every stage of the proceedings. The shifty eye, the hangdog look, out

document.text: W oman G ets Damage. Roanoke, Va., Sept. 16 For six days the Circuit Conrt of Franklin county, sitting at Rooky Mount, has heard the slander suit of Miss Dora Lee Atoheson against John C. Shearer. Today the jury brought in a verdict for Miss Atoheson giv ing her 500 and requiring the de fendant to pay the costs. Miss Acthesop is a milliner from Balti- mor -. At one time she was em ployed in a store in Rocky Mount. Reports damaging to her oharacter were circnlated there. She brought suit against Shearer, with whom she at one time boarded, and also against D. W. Angle. The trial of the Shearer suit came up first. The amount sued for was 5,000. Unless compromised in some way, the Angle suit will be heard next. Miss Atcheson was employed in Angles store.  A number of the most prominent lawyers in the county were engaged in the case, among them, being Con gressman E. W. Saunders, who ap peared for the defense.Times- Dispatch.

document.text: W hat Our Law M akers Are do ing at the Capital. The past Aveek has been a busy one for our Legislative. They are doing good work, and demonstrate in numerous ways that they are a capa ble, intelligent and dignified body. The following are a few of the bills of general interest By Mr. Saunders To provide that process for a witness issued dur- ng the trial of a criminal prosecution in a court of record may be executed by the officer of the court from which the process issues in any coun ty or corporation of the State. By same To enable commission ers in chancery to compel the atten dance of witnesses summoned to appear before them. By Mr. Murrell To amend and re-euact section 3695 of the Code in reference to extorting money, c. by threats, and providing therefor a penalty of confinement in the peni ternary for not less than three nor more than five years, or at the dia cretion of the jury, confinement in jail not exceeding one year and a fine not exceeding 1,000. By Mr. Flood To amend the Code in relation to State depositaries, their bonds, when money to be transferred, Ac. Mr. Miller presented a bill to ere ate the office of road engineer for Virginia. This bill provides that said road engineer shall have a salary of 1,800 per annum and traveling expenses shall give bond in the sum of 5,000 for the faithful discharge of his duties shall investigate the condition of the roads of the Com monwealth and report thereon with suggestions to each Legislature, anc whenever called on by the author! ties of any county for aid and advice touching the highways and bridges of said county, he shall give it.
